title: Republican Senate leader blasts city for not turning in immigrant
text:
New York Republican Senate leader blasts city for not turning in Salvadoran immigrant with alleged gang ties Republican Senate leader blasts city for not turning in immigrant Senate Majority Leader John Flanagan (R-Smithtown) is opposed to legislation that would make New York a sanctuary state. (Hans Pennink/AP) NEW YORK DAILY NEWS Wednesday, February 22, 2017, 5:13 PM 
ALBANY — The state’s most powerful Republican on Wednesday slammed city officials for failing to turn over a 19-year-old Salvadoran immigrant with alleged gang ties to federal immigration authorities. 
“I think public safety should prevail over everything else,” State Senate Majority Leader John Flanagan (R-Suffolk County) told reporters at the Capitol. 
“If the New York City administration is flouting the law, shame on them and that should be fixed,” Flanagan added. 
City officials last week allowed undocumented immigrant Estivan Velasquez to be released from Rikers Island despite a detainer order having been issued for him by ICE. 
Mayor de Blasio rips feds for deporting Queens immigrant 
Velasquez, who had served nearly five months for disorderly conduct, was later arrested by ICE in Queens. Federal officials describe him as a gang member and a potential threat to public safety. 
Mayor de Blasio on Tuesday lashed out at federal authorities for arresting Velasquez, arguing there was not enough evidence to support allegations that he was a gang member. Under its so-called “sanctuary city” policy, the city does not hand over undocumented people who have been arrested to ICE officials unless they committed one of 170 crimes deemed serious enough to merit deportation. (Charles Reed/AP)

De Blasio has insisted that New York will remain a “ sanctuary city ” despite threats from President Trump to withhold federal aid. 
NYPD won't round up immigrants under Trump's deportation orders 
Flanagan on Wednesday reiterated his opposition to legislation that would make New York a “sanctuary state.” 
“You can take that as a given,” Flanagan said during an interview on public radio’s “The Capitol Pressroom” when asked if the Senate would oppose the legislation. Tags:
